Award.AwardTitle: Random Matrix Models and Statistical Mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project has an interdisciplinary character on the frontier between physics and mathematics. The project investigates the phenomena of scaling and universality in random matrices, which are central in many areas of modern science. Improved understanding of these phenomena will have a significant impact on both mathematical theory and its applications. The project aims to develop new and powerful mathematical approaches involving methods from different areas of mathematics including analysis, the theory of integrable systems, probability theory, semiclassical asymptotics, and complex analysis. The results of the project will have direct applications to combinatorial aspects of quantum gravity, exactly solvable models of statistical mechanics, spin systems on random surfaces, theory of critical phenomena and phase transitions, and quantum chaos. Further applications include the theory of knots and links and related problems in molecular biology, growth models, and statistical data analysis.

This research project is directed at fundamental problems of the theory of random matrix models and statistical mechanics. The project investigates different conjectures of universality of the scaling limits of eigenvalue correlation functions and exactly solvable models of statistical physics and hydrodynamics. This includes: (a) the development of the Riemann-Hilbert approach to random normal matrix models with applications to Hele-Shaw flows in hydrodynamics, Laplacian growth, and quantum Hall effect; (b) the development of the Riemann-Hilbert approach to random matrix models with external source, including the problems of phase transitions, critical phenomena, and double scaling limits in these models; (c) the exact solution of the six-vertex model with various boundary conditions in different phases; and (d) the study of the phase separation in the six-vertex model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we have investigated and solved various important problems in the theory of random matrices and statistical physics:

  1. Together with Guilherme Silva, we have finished a big project on a new phenomenon of the mother body phase transition in the ensemble of normal random matrices. This can have important applications to solid state physics and the quantum Hall effect, in particular. On the results of our studies we have prepared a detailed manuscript, 127 pages. The manuscript has been published in the prestigious Memoirs of the American Mathematical Society (2020).
  2. The scaling and universality of the Lee--Yang zeros in the Ising model on the Diamond Hierarchical Lattices has been investigated in our joint project with Mikhail Lyubich and Roland Roeder. This project lies on the frontier of physics and mathematics and it involves a variety of deep ideas and methods from complex dynamics and statistical mechanics. The results of our studies have been summarized in two detailed manuscripts. Part I has been published in the Journal des Mathematiques Pures et Appliques (2017). Part II has been published in the Journal of Geometric Analysis (2020).
  3. Together with Karl Liechty, we obtained an exact solution of the six-vertex model of statistical mechanics with half-turn boundary conditions. We developed the Riemann--Hilbert approach to the model, and we obtained an asymptotic expansion of the partition function. This model has important applications to ferroelectricity. The paper has been published in the journal Constructive Approximation (2018).
  4. The topological expansion and phase transitions in the complex cubic random matrix model (joint project with Alfredo Deano and Maxim Yattselev). We developed the powerful Riemann--Hilbert approach to the asymptotic solution of the cubic random matrix model with complex coefficients and its applications to graph enumeration on Riemannian surfaces and quantum gravity.  The results of our studies have been published in the Journal of Statistical Physics (2017).
  5. Exact solution for the monomer-monomer correlation function in the dimer model on the triangular lattice. Together with Estelle Basor (AIM) we develop an exact solution for the monomer-monomer correlation function in the dimer model on the triangular lattice. The solution is based on an extension of the Borodin--Okounkov--Case--Geronimo formula to matrix symbols and on the exact Wiener--Hopf--Birkhoff--Grothendick factorization of matrix symbol appearing in the dimer model on the triangular lattice. The results of our studies have been summarized in a detailed paper published in the journal Communications in Mathematical Physics (2017).
  6. The Pfaffian Sign Theorem. Together with my graduate students Brad Elwood and Drazen Petrovic we proved the Pfaffian Sign Theorem for the dimer model on the triangular lattice. Namely, we proved that in the Kasteleyn solution for the partition function the sign of the first Pfaffian is negative, while the other three Pfaffians are positive. This result corrects previous results of several physical papers. The paper is published in the Journal of Statistical Physics (2018). We also obtained an asymptotic expansion of the partition function for the dimer model on the square lattice. The coefficients of the asymptotic expansions are beautifully expressed in terms of classical automorphic functions, the Jacobi theta functions, the Dedekind eta function, and the Kronecker double series. The paper has been published in the Journal of Mathematical Physics (2018).
  7.  A Thouless-Like Effect in the Dyson Hierarchical Model with Continuous Symmetry (joint project with Peter Major). We proved a conjecture of Dyson. This conjecture states a necessary and sufficient condition of the existence of phase transition in the model under consideration, and it states that the spontaneous magnetization vanishes at the critical point, i.e., there is no Thouless' effect. We find, however, that the distribution of the normalized average spin at the critical temperature tends to the uniform distribution on the unit sphere as the volume tends to infinity, a phenomenon which resembles the Thouless effect. Our paper has been accepted for publication in the journal of Pure and Applied Functional Analysis.
